'''''Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca''''', commonly known as the '''false chanterelle''', is a species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Hygrophoropsidaceae]].
It is found across several continents, growing in woodland and [[heathland]], and sometimes on [[woodchips]] used in gardening and landscaping. [[Basidiocarp|Fruit bodies]] ([[mushroom]]s) are yellow–orange with a funnel-shaped [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|8|cm|in|abbr=on|frac=8}} across that has a felt-like surface. The thin, often forked [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] on the underside of the cap run partway down the length of the otherwise smooth [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]. Reports on the mushroom's [[edible mushroom|edibility]] vary – it can serve as food, though not a particularly flavorful one, or it can be mildly [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]].

Austrian naturalist [[Franz Xaver von Wulfen]] described the false chanterelle in 1781, noting both its resemblance with the true [[Cantharellus|chanterelles]] and people's propensity to confuse them. The false chanterelle was then placed in the genus ''[[Clitocybe]]'', but it was later observed that its forked gills and [[dextrinoid]] spores indicated a relationship to ''[[Paxillus]]''. Genetic analysis has confirmed that it belongs to the order [[Boletales]] and is more closely related to [[bolete]]s.

==Taxonomy==
Austrian naturalist Franz Xaver von Wulfen described the false chanterelle as ''Agaricus aurantiacus'' in 1781, reporting that it appeared in the [[Abies|fir]] tree forests around [[Klagenfurt]] in October. He added that it could be confused with the chanterelle by the inexperienced, but that its true nature was very different; in contrast to its edible lookalike, he described it as "kind of pernicious".<ref name="Jacquin 1781"/> The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] is the [[Latin]] word ''aurantiacus'', meaning "orange".<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> [[James Sowerby]] illustrated it and gave it the name ''Agaricus subcantharellus'', describing it as a "perhaps unfavourable" variety of ''A. cantharellus'' (chanterelle).<ref name="Sowerby 1809"/> The fungus was placed in the genus ''[[Merulius]]'' by [[Johann Friedrich Gmelin]] in 1792,<ref name="Gmelin 1792"/> and then ''[[Cantharellus]]'' by [[Elias Fries]] in 1821.<ref name="Fries 1821"/> [[Bernhard Studer-Steinhäuslin]] concluded it could only be classified in the genus ''[[Clitocybe]]'' in 1900, based on its white spores, [[decurrent]] gills and lack of a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]].<ref name="Studer 1900"/> It was elevated to the status of genus in Emile Martin-Sans' 1929 publication ''L'Empoisonnement par les champignons et particulièrement les intoxications dues aux Agaricacées du groupe des Clitocybe et du groupe des Cortinarius'', with authorship attributed to [[René Maire]]. Martin-Sans concurred with Maire's assessment of ''Hygrophoropsis'', suggesting that it represented a form intermediate between ''Cantharellus'' and ''Clitocybe'', and was thus worthy of generic ranking.<ref name="Martin-Sans 1929"/> The genus name refers to a resemblance to the genus ''[[Hygrophorus]]''.<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> It is commonly known as the false chanterelle.<ref name="BMS"/>
[[File:Coloured Figures of English Fungi or Mushrooms - t. 413.jpg|thumb|left|James Sowerby's 1809 illustration of ''Agaricus subcantharellus'']]

Two [[variety (botany)|varieties]] described by [[Derek Reid]] in 1972, ''H. aurantiaca'' var. ''macrospora'' and ''H. aurantiaca'' var. ''rufa'',<ref name="Reid 1972"/> have since been promoted to distinct species status as ''[[Hygrophoropsis macrospora|H. macrospora]]'' (1996)<ref name="Boekhout 1996"/> and ''[[Hygrophoropsis rufa|H. rufa]]'' (2008).<ref name="Knudsen 2008"/> Two other varieties of the fungus have been described, but they are not considered to have independent [[taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] significance by [[Index Fungorum]]:<ref name="urlFungorum synonymy: Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca"/> var. ''nana'' (Singer 1946), characterized by a small fruit body;<ref name="Singer 1946"/> and var. ''robusta'' (Antonín 2000), characterized by a robust fruit body and an odour similar to [[Maggi]] seasoning sauce.<ref name="Antonín 2000"/> Pale forms of the fungus are sometimes referred to as var. ''pallida''. This [[taxon]] was first published by [[Robert Kühner]] and [[Henri Romagnesi]] in 1953,<ref name="Kühner 1953"/> but later considered [[validly published name|invalid]] as it did not conform to [[International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants|nomenclatural rules]].<ref name="urlFungorum: Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca var. pallida"/> Variety ''nigripes'', a taxon with a black-brown [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]], is invalid for similar reasons.<ref name="Holec 2013"/> ''H. aurantiaca'' var. ''pallida'' was published validly in 1995.<ref name="Heykoop 1995"/>

In 1979, [[Egon Horak]] suggested that ''H. aurantiaca'' and the New Zealand taxon ''[[Hygrophoropsis coacta|H. coacta]]'' were the same species,<ref name="Horak 1979"/> but neither Index Fungorum nor [[MycoBank]] accept this synonymy. According to MycoBank, ''H. aurantiaca'' has several heterotypic synonyms, i.e. different [[type (biology)|types]] but considered the same species:<ref name="urlMycoBank: Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca"/>
*''Agaricus alectorolophoides'' [[Jacob Christian Schäffer|Schaeff.]] (1774)<ref name="Schaeffer 1774"/>
*''Agaricus subcantharellus'' [[James Sowerby|Sowerby]] (1809)<ref name="Sowerby 1809"/>
*''Cantharellus brachypodus'' [[François Fulgis Chevallier|Chevall.]] (1826)<ref name="Chevallier 1826"/>
*''Cantharellus ravenelii'' [[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berk.]] & [[Moses Ashley Curtis|M.A.Curtis]] (1853)<ref name="Berkeley 1853"/>
*''Merulius brachypodes'' (Chevall.) [[Otto Kuntze|Kuntze]] (1891)<ref name="Kuntze 1891"/>

''Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca'' has been confused with the true chanterelles (genus ''Cantharellus'') because of overall similarities in appearance.<ref name="Jacquin 1781"/> However, the forked gills, frequently off-centre stipe placement, and [[dextrinoid]] spores of ''H. aurantiaca'' suggested a relationship with ''[[Paxillus]]'',<ref name="Arora 1986"/> prompting [[Rolf Singer]] to classify the genus ''Hygrophoropsis'' in the family [[Paxillaceae]] in 1946.<ref name="Singer 1946"/> Several [[biological pigment|pigments]] have been identified from the fungus, including the orange [[variegatic acid]], [[methyl variegate]], the red [[variegatorubin]], and several [[derivative (chemistry)|derivatives]] of [[pulvinic acid]].<ref name="Besl 1978"/> The presence of these pigments suggests a [[chemotaxonomy|chemotaxic]] relationship with the [[Boletaceae]], [[Coniophoraceae]], and Paxillaceae—families of Boletales with members that have similar compounds.<ref name="Bas 1995"/><ref name="Nelson 2010"/> [[Molecular phylogenetic]] analysis confirmed its affinity lay in the order [[Boletales]] in 1997,<ref name="Binder 1997"/> though later research showed it is not closely related to ''Paxillus'' or other gilled members of the order.<ref name="Binder 2006"/>

==Description==
[[File:Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca 52882.jpg|thumb|left|Underside of cap showing orange, forked gills and inrolled rim]]
The false chanterelle has a golden-orange [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|8|cm|in|abbr=on|frac=8}} across, initially convex but becoming funnel-shaped as the mushroom matures. The cap margin, which remains rolled in a little,<ref name="Kibby 2012"/> becomes wavy or lobed in age.<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> The cap surface is covered with a fine down. The [[decurrent]] gill-like structures are narrow and forked, which is a distinctive and distinguishing feature. They are generally a more intense shade of orange than the cap.<ref name="Kibby 2012"/> Along the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]], the gills may be slightly crimped.<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> The orange stipe is {{convert|3|–|5|cm|in|abbr=on|frac=8}} high and {{convert|0.5|–|1|cm|in|1|abbr=on|frac=8}} thick, and lacks a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]].<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> It often has a darker, brownish, base.<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> The ability to form [[sclerotia]] (compact masses of hardened fungal [[mycelium]]) has been documented for ''H. aurantiaca'' in laboratory studies. These structures contain [[glycogen]] and [[protein]] that may be used as food reserves during spore [[germination]].<ref name="Antibus 1989"/>

The soft, thin [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] ranges from white to yellowish<ref name="Buczacki 2012"/> to golden-orange.<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> It has an odour and taste described variously as indistinct,<ref name="Desjarden 2014"/> or unpleasant and earthy.<ref name="Buczacki 2012"/> The [[spore print]] is white to [[cream (colour)|cream]].<ref name="Arora 1986"/> The oval [[basidiospore|spores]] are 5.5–7 by 4–4.5 [[micrometre]]s (µm),<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> with walls that tend to thicken in age.<ref name="Smith 1975"/> The spores are [[cyanophilous]], meaning they will readily [[staining|stain]] dark blue in [[methyl blue]] solution.<ref name="Singer 1972"/> Staining with [[Melzer's reagent]] often produces a [[dextrinoid]] (reddish-brown) colour reaction.<ref name="Arora 1986"/> [[Basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) measure 25–40 by 5–8 µm,<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> and can be two-, three-, or four-spored.<ref name="Smith 1975"/> [[Cystidia]] (large sterile cells on the [[hymenium]]) are absent.<ref name="Smith 1975"/> The [[cap cuticle]] is in the form of a trichoderm, where the outermost [[hypha]]e are roughly parallel, like hairs, perpendicular to the cap surface. These hyphae are 4–15 µm in diameter,<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> and contain intracellular pigments that impart an orange-brown to yellow-brown colouring to the cells. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the hyphae.<ref name="Smith 1975"/>

[[Teratology|Teratological]] (developmentally abnormal) forms of ''H. aurantiaca'' were reported to occur in the United Kingdom. The fruit bodies of these specimens were club-shaped with a wrinkled upper surface of convoluted gill tissue. The overall [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] of these forms somewhat resembles species of ''[[Clavariadelphus]]''. Although the cause of this abnormal development is not known with certainty, environmental pollutants or [[mycovirus|virus]] infection have been suggested as contributing factors.<ref name="Spooner 2014"/>

===Similar species===
{{multiple image|perrow = 2|total_width=300
 | align = right
 | image1 = 2007-07-14 Cantharellus cibarius2.jpg
 |width1 = 849 | height1 = 725
 | image2 = 2007-08-05 Omphalotus illudens (Schwein.) Bresinsky & Besl 1018098506.jpg
 |width2 = 1200 | height2 = 800
 | image3 = Chrysomphalina chrysophylla 419148.jpg
 |width3 = 2584 | height3 = 1909
 | image4 = 2008-10-19 Hygrophoropsis morganii (Peck) H.E. Bigelow 25987 mod.jpg
 |width4 = 2000 | height4 = 1580
 | footer = Lookalike species. Clockwise from upper left: ''[[Cantharellus cibarius]]'', ''[[Omphalotus illudens]]'', ''[[Aphroditeola olida]]'', ''[[Chrysomphalina chrysophylla]]''.
}}
Characteristics typically used in the field to distinguish ''Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca'' from lookalike species include: the soft, dry consistency of its cap; the crowded, decurrent, and forked gills that are [[saffron (color)|saffron]] to orange coloured; and the lack of any distinctive taste or odour.<ref name="Smith 1975"/> The false chanterelle can be distinguished from the true chanterelle (''Cantharellus cibarius'') by its deeper orange colour, brown base to the stipe, velvety cap surface, forked gills rather than gill-like ridges, softer (and thinner) flesh, and lack of the characteristic apricot-smell.<ref name="Lamaison 2005"/> The cap surface of ''[[Hygrophoropsis fuscosquamula]]'', found in Britain, has fine brown scales overlaying a dull orange background.<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> ''H. rufa'' has velvety brown fur covering its cap, while ''H. macrospora'' has cream gills and stipe. Microscopically, these three species have larger spores than ''H. aurantiaca''.<ref name="Kibby 2012"/><!-- cites previous 2 sentences --> ''[[Hygrophoropsis tapinia|H. tapinia]]'', found in a range extending from southern [[Florida]] to Central America,<ref name="Gómez-Pignataro 1992"/> is set apart from ''H. aurantiaca'' by its growth on or under deciduous trees (never conifers), and smaller spores, which measure 3.3–4.8 by 2.5–3.3 µm.<ref name="Singer 1946"/>

Formerly a member of ''Hygrophoropsis'', ''[[Aphroditeola olida]]'' is also similar in appearance to ''H. aurantiaca'' but can be distinguished from the false chanterelle by its smaller, pinkish fruit bodies and candy-like odour.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> It also has smaller spores.<ref name="Kibby 2012"/> ''[[Chrysomphalina chrysophylla]]'' has a yellowish brown cap and unforked yellow gills.<ref name="Desjarden 2014"/> ''[[Cortinarius hesleri]]'', an eastern North American species that associates with oaks, has a rusty brown spore print and a [[partial veil|cortina]] in young specimens.<ref name="Kuo 2014"/> The poisonous [[Omphalotus|jack-o'-lantern mushroom]]s (genus ''Omphalotus'') comprise another group of lookalikes; however, they have straight, non-forked true gills.<ref name="Bresinsky 1990"/> The European wood-rotting species ''[[Haasiella splendidissima]]'',{{#tag:ref|This taxon is given in the original source as ''Haasiella venustissima''; molecular analysis published in 2012 indicates that this is the same species as ''H. splendidissima''.<ref name="Vizzini 2012"/>|group=nb}} sometimes confused with ''H. aurantiaca'', is most readily distinguished from the latter by its pink spore print and gills that do not fork.<ref name="Buczacki 2012"/>

==Distribution, habitat, and ecology==
[[File:Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca 562212.jpg|thumb|left|Collection from [[Pennsylvania]]]]
''Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca'' is a widely distributed species. In Europe and North America, it is found in both [[hardwood]] and [[conifer]] forests, as well as heathland, in summer and autumn.<ref name="Miller 2006"/> In Mexico, it is common in coniferous forests.<ref name="Guzman 1973"/> It fruits from the ground or from decaying wood,<ref name="Miller 2006"/> on burned areas in forests,<ref name="Smith 1975"/> and is often found near fallen trees and tree stumps.<ref name="Haas 1969"/> The fungus can also grow on [[woodchips]] used in gardening and landscaping, and so it also appears on roadsides and other locations where this material is used.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> Fruit bodies occur singly to scattered, or in clusters,<ref name="Desjarden 2014"/> and can be very abundant.<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> Generally considered a dry weather mushroom, it can be plentiful when other mushrooms are scarce.<ref name="Smith 1975"/> Other locations where the false chanterelle has been recorded include Africa,<ref name="Ambali 2008"/> Central and South America, northern Asia, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> Populations in [[California]] represent a [[species complex|complex]] of undescribed species that are collectively referred to as ''Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca'' ''[[sensu lato]]''.<ref name="Desjarden 2014"/>

A [[saprophytic]] fungus, ''H. aurantiaca'' obtains nutrients from [[forest floor|forest litter]] and decomposing wood,<ref name="Kuo 2014"/> causing a [[Wood-decay fungus#Brown rot|brown rot]] on the wood upon which it grows.<ref name="Fransson 2004"/>

''H. aurantiaca'' secretes large amounts of [[oxalic acid]], a [[reducing agent]] and relatively [[strong acid]]. This stimulates [[weathering]] of the [[humus]] layer of forest soil, and influences the solubility and turnover of nutrients (particularly [[phosphorus]] and [[nitrogen]]), which in turn affects their availability for use by forest trees.<ref name="Fransson 2004"/>

==Edibility==
The false chanterelle has been described as [[edible mushroom|edible]] (though not tasty) by some experts,<ref name="Arora 1986"/><ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/><ref name="Ammirati 1987"/> but other authors report it as potentially [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]].<ref name="Miller 2006"/><ref name="Jordan 2004"/> Indeed, Fries described it as ''venenatus'', meaning "poisonous", in 1821.<ref name="Fries 1821"/> [[David Arora]] speculates that the confusion about edibility may be a result of misidentification with the similar-looking but definitely poisonous ''[[Omphalotus]]'' species.<ref name="Arora 1986"/> However, [[extract]]s made from Nigerian collections were mildly toxic to mice.<ref name="Ambali 2008"/> Some people experience gastrointestinal symptoms after eating the mushroom, possibly due to its high levels of the [[sugar alcohol]] [[arabitol]].<ref name="Lindgren 2003"/> It was eaten, though not especially highly regarded, by the [[Zapotec people]] of [[Ixtlán de Juárez]] in [[Oaxaca]].<ref name="Garibay 2007"/> The [[Tepehuán people]] of northwestern Mexico also occasionally eat the mushroom, which they refer to in their [[Tepehuán language|native language]] as ''guin'xacan'' ("delightful") or ''kia's gio''' ("iguana lard"); there, it is commonly prepared by roasting over charcoal, or boiling and garnishing with cheese.<ref name="Elizondo 1991"/>
